title: 110_s2812
content: The Medicare Telehealth Improvement Act of 2008, also known as the Act, includes provisions such as an increase in the types of originating sites and the expansion of practitioners eligible to provide telehealth services. It aims to improve the process for updating the list of telehealth services. The Medicare Telehealth Improvement Act of 2008 expands the types of originating sites eligible for telehealth services, including skilled nursing facilities, renal dialysis facilities, community mental health centers, qualified community programs, county mental health clinics, and any other site with a telecommunications system. The Medicare Telehealth Improvement Act of 2008 broadens the range of originating sites eligible for telehealth services, including mental health clinics and sites with a telecommunications system. No facility fee is required for certain originating sites. The Medicare Telehealth Improvement Act of 2008 expands eligible originating sites for telehealth services, with no facility fee required for certain sites. Amendments made by this section will apply to services provided 90 days after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 3. Expansion of practitioners eligible to furnish telehealth services. Expansion of practitioners eligible to furnish telehealth services by amending the definition of "practitioner" in the Social Security Act to include physical therapists, occupational therapists, and qualified speech-language pathologists. The Social Security Act is amended to include physical therapists, occupational therapists, speech-language pathologists, audiologists, certified providers, and other individuals or entities as eligible practitioners for telehealth services. The effective date for these changes is 90 days after the enactment of the Act. The Social Security Act is amended to include various healthcare practitioners for telehealth services, with an effective date 90 days after the enactment of the Act. Additionally, there is a provision for the improvement of the process for updating the list of telehealth services. The Social Security Act is amended to establish a Telehealth Advisory Committee to provide recommendations on adding or deleting telehealth services. If the Secretary does not implement a recommendation, they must provide a reason in the Federal Register. The Telehealth Advisory Committee, established under the Social Security Act, consists of 7 members appointed by the Secretary of Health and Human Services to recommend additions or deletions of services for authorized payment under section 1834(m). The Telehealth Advisory Committee consists of 7 members appointed by the Secretary of Health and Human Services, including five practicing physicians and two non-physician health care providers with experience in telemedicine or telehealth. The Telehealth Advisory Committee members must have experience in telemedicine or telehealth, with a balance of specialties and geographic regions. The Secretary determines their terms of service. The Telehealth Advisory Committee members must have experience in telemedicine or telehealth, with a balance of specialties and geographic regions. The Advisory Committee shall meet twice per year and at such other times as it may provide. The Secretary shall establish the Advisory Committee notwithstanding any limitation that may apply to the number of advisory committees that may be established.
